controlProperties.title: Non White (%)
controlProperties.tooltip: The percentage of people who don't consider themselves white only. For example, the bar positioned at 0.5 shows you areas in which the area's population is 50% non-white. Hence, the higher the percentage, the higher number of people of color in that area.

controlProperties.title: Median Household Income
controlProperties.tooltip: Poorer neighborhoods and areas with more residents of color experience hotter temperatures in the summer and are more likely to work outside and live in denser housing with inadequate infrastructure. Additionally, people in areas more vulnerable to heat risks with lower income are less likely to have access to health care.

controlProperties.title: Morning Max Heat Index
controlProperties.tooltip: The maximum heat index recorded during the morning of the campaign in a given census block

controlProperties.title: Afternoon Max Heat Index
controlProperties.tooltip: The maximum heat index recorded during the afternoon of the campaign in a given census block

controlProperties.title: Evening Max Heat Index
controlProperties.tooltip: The maximum heat index recorded during the evening of the campaign in a given census block

controlProperties.title: Grade
controlProperties.tooltip: The redline grade from worst D (represented as 1) to best A (represented as 4)

stories.title: Getting Started
stories.content:
This story map can be used to visualize the results of NYC and northeastern NJ's 2021 urban heat island mapping campaign combined with personal experience stories about extreme heat, as well as historical and demographic information that show how heat connects to social inequities and health disparities.

To see different data visualizations, first select layers (see top right on the map) and then adjust your options from the 'CONTROLS' panel.

Do you live within the study area (Northern Manhattan, South Bronx, Jersey City, Newark, and Elizabeth) and would like to tell your story about extreme heat here?
Please submit your story here for a chance to win a $50 gift card.

stories.title: Heat + traffic + pollution + odors
stories.content: From Dr. Melissa Barber: I live on Bruckner Boulevard, between Alexander and Willis Avenues, directly adjacent to the Willis Avenue Bridge. Heat during the summer months is completely exhausting because it not only brings the smell of hot trash from the waste transfer station, exacerbates the smog of the heavy highway traffic that usually starts about 5 am and reminds me of the ensuing high electric bill from the use of fans and air conditioners, there is very little tree coverage or shade to block the sun's rays or cool even the outside temperatures. From the moment Lilah and I leave the building, heat hits us and follows us throughout the entire neighborhood

stories.title: Brutal even for the young and healthy
stories.content: I endured two hot summers in Washington Heights before installing an air conditioner. I was young and healthy, but it was still brutal. Cooking made the heat worse, and I worked at a bakery where no amount of air conditioning could keep up with the oven.

stories.title: The #1 Bus Chronicles
stories.content: From Joel Katz: as a the director of the documentary film The #1 Bus Chronicles, I spent countless hours at a bus stop at the intersection of Hackensack Ave. and Routes 1&9 in South Kearny, NJ. Weather conditions ranged from mid-blizzard to scorching heat. There's a bus shelter on only one side of the highway, and no water fountain anywhere nearby. During extreme heat it was absolutely withering

stories.title: Heat Deaths in Harlem, 1880-1940
stories.content: Kemuning A. Adiputri's story map on heat prostration shows historic heat victims across the study area between 1880-1940, utilizing point addresses gained through historical newspapers in a randomized arrangement. This map aims to understand a pattern of reported heat victims (not to incorporate all victim data throughout history) to give a better understanding of what possible factors are behind those samplings.

stories.title: Life without shade trees
stories.content:
Shade trees are typically overlooked for their ability to cool urban areas. Shade trees are mature street trees that are able to shade surfaces underneath as well as cool the air around them. When urban areas exist without trees, people must get creative to escape extreme heat. Here skateboarders use the shade of the NJ Turnpike Extension to shade themselves.
Here a man sits in the shade of a building
Businesses on the side of the street with no shade get less foot traffic

stories.title: No green in our 'green space'
stories.content:
How good is a 'green' space when there is little to no green to be found? That's the situation we face in the South Bronx. So-called 'parks' and 'playgrounds' designated as 'green space' by the City are often concrete slabs with very little tree canopy. See below for examples of what some of these spaces look like.

Carlos Lozada

Clark Playground

Graham Triangle 138th St side

Pulaski

Ranaqua

Willis Playground 140 extension

stories.title: Walking to the corner store in the heat
stories.content: Summers in extreme heat, very little green space to cool down under. Walking to the corner store was enough for my asthma to act up and to feel exhausted and worn down by the sun.
